properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Kerang, Pyramid Creek.

  • There is a hayshed fire at Kerang-Koondrook Rd, Kerang that is under control.
  • This Advice message replaces the Community Information issued at 12:58 PM on 8 November 2023. 
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are attending to this fire. 
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2023 09:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - GRASS FIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Kerang-Koondrook Rd, Kerang
Issue Date: Wednesday 08 November 2023, 01:02 pm
Next Update: Thursday 09 November 2023, 09:00 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/30925/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Kerang, Pyramid Creek.

- There is a hayshed fire at Kerang-Koondrook Rd, Kerang that is under control.
- This Advice message replaces the Community Information issued at 12:58 PM on 8 November 2023. 


There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and monitor conditions.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: East Gippsland and West and South Gippsland
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for East Gippsland and West and South Gippsland.
  • We are seeing an increase in people suffering asthma symptoms across parts of Victoria.
  • People may experience asthma symptoms or difficulty breathing due to the combination of thunderstorm activity and high grass pollen levels.
  • If you’re experiencing wheezing, breathlessness, a feeling of tightness in the chest or a persistent cough, you may be having an asthma attack.
  • An asthma attack is serious and can be life threatening.
  • If you develop symptoms follow your asthma management plan, or if you don’t have a plan follow the four steps of asthma first aid.
Be aware of an increased chance of having an asthma attack or breathing difficulties and take precautions.

Call Triple Zero (000) immediately if someone is not breathing, if their asthma suddenly becomes worse or is not improving, or if the person is having an asthma attack and a reliever is not available.

What you should do:

What you should do:
  • If you have asthma or have a history of asthma or hay fever, carry a reliever puffer (usually blue) on you at all times today. 
  • Avoid the wind gusts before the storm. Go inside and close your windows and doors.
  • Turn off air conditioners that bring in air from the outside (ie evaporative air conditioners).
If you are experiencing asthma symptoms for the first time:
  • Don’t ignore them, see your doctor to make a diagnosis and if severe call Triple Zero (000).
  • If required, use asthma first aid. Remember that asthma relievers are available from pharmacies without a prescription. 
  • Make sure you follow up with your doctor.
  • Call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24 or see your doctor if you require medical advice.
  • You can visit a Priority Primary Care Centres (PPCCs) who provide GP-led care to people who need urgent care, but not an emergency response. 
Impacts in your area:
  • Health services are reporting an increase in people experiencing asthma symptoms and breathing difficulties. 
This message was issued by the Deputy Chief Health Officer.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2023 01:00 am or as the situation changes.

For more information:
  • For more information on what thunderstorm asthma is, visit the Better Health Channel.
  • Monitor epidemic thunderstorm asthma forecasts.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#thunderstormasthma)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Be aware of an increased chance of having an asthma attack or breathing difficulties and take precautions. Call Triple Zero (000) immediately if someone is not breathing, if their asthma suddenly becomes worse or is not improving, or if the person is having an asthma attack and a reliever is not available.

properties.name: Advice

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for the North East weather district.
  • We are seeing an increase in people suffering asthma symptom across parts of Victoria. 
  • People may experience asthma symptoms or difficulty breathing due to the combination of thunderstorm activity and high grass pollen levels. 
  • If you’re experiencing wheezing, breathlessness, a feeling of tightness in the chest or a persistent cough, you may be having an asthma attack. 
  • An asthma attack is serious and can be life threatening. 
If you develop asthma symptoms, follow your asthma action plan, or if you don’t have a plan, follow the four steps of asthma first aid.
Be aware of an increased chance of having an asthma attack or breathing difficulties and take precautions. 

Call Triple Zero (000) immediately if someone is not breathing, if their asthma suddenly becomes worse or is not improving, or if the person is having an asthma attack and a reliever is not available.

What you should do:


What you should do:

  • If you have asthma or have a history of asthma or hay fever, carry a reliever puffer (usually blue) on you at all times 
  • Avoid the wind gusts before the storm. Go inside and close your windows and doors before and during the storm. 
  • Turn off air-conditioners that brings outdoor air inside (eg evaporative air-conditioning).  
If you are experiencing asthma symptoms for the first time: 
  • Don’t ignore them, see your doctor to make a diagnosis and if severe call Triple Zero (000). 
  • If required, use asthma first aid. Remember that asthma relievers are available from pharmacies without a prescription. 
  • Make sure you follow up with your doctor.
  • Call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24 or see your doctor if you require medical advice.

You can visit a Priority Primary Care Centres (PPCCs) who provide GP-led care to people who need urgent care, but not an emergency response.


Asthma First Aid 

If a person is having an asthma attack, use the four steps of asthma first aid: 

Step 1: Sit the person upright 

Step 2: Give four separate puffs of blue or grey reliever puffer,  make sure you shake the puffer, put one puff into the spacer and get the person to take four breaths from the spacer. Repeat this until the person has taken four puffs. 

Step 3: Wait four minutes. If there is no improvement, give the person four more separate puffs, as in step two. 

Step 4: If there is still no improvement, dial Triple Zero (000) for an ambulance. Keep giving the person four separate puffs every four minutes until emergency assistance arrives. If you don’t have a spacer, simply inhale four puffs directly by mouth. 

Call Triple Zero (000) immediately if someone is not breathing, if their asthma suddenly becomes worse, or if someone is having a severe asthma attack. 

If you’re not sure that it’s asthma, call Triple Zero (000) immediately. 

Using asthma reliever medication in an emergency when breathing is difficult is unlikely to cause harm, even if the person doesn’t have asthma.
Impacts in your area:
  • Health services are reporting an increase in people experiencing asthma symptoms and breathing difficulties. 
  • We are seeing an increase in people suffering from asthma and breathing difficulties in parts of Victoria.
  • We are in peak grass pollen season, so it is important that people with asthma remember to carry their asthma medication at all times.  
This message was issued by the Deputy Chief Health Officer.

The next update is expected by 09/11/2023 05:00 am or as the situation changes.

For more information:
  • For more information on what thunderstorm asthma is, visit the Better Health Channel.
  • Monitor epidemic thunderstorm asthma forecasts.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#thunderstormasthma)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

If you develop asthma symptoms, follow your asthma action plan, or if you don’t have a plan, follow the four steps of asthma first aid. Be aware of an increased chance of having an asthma attack or breathing difficulties and take precautions. Call Triple Zero (000) immediately if someone is not breathing, if their asthma suddenly becomes worse or is not improving, or if the person is having an asthma attack and a reliever is not available.
